reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Long-term protection and monitoring of the Rakhine Yoma Elephant Range, Myanmar. Long-Term Protection and Monitoring of the Rakhine Yoma Elephant Range, Myanmar.

description.narrative: This three-year project aims to maintain and enhance the protection of wild Asian elephants in the Rakhine Yoma Elephant Range (RYER) in Myanmar through continued engagement with Elephant Protection Units (EPU), provision of training and support, and patrol gear to improve patrol performance and morale. Project activities include: 1) increase the operational effectiveness of existing EPUs and expand coverage by hiring additional captive Myanma Timber Enterprise (MTE) elephants; 2) upgrade ranger substations and provisions of boats; 3) increase effectiveness of patrols through adaptive SMART patrol methodology; 4) identify elephant distribution and hotspots; and 5) regular analysis of satellite imagery to monitor and respond to forest encroachment and shifting cultivation within RYER. This project will maintain and enhance the protection of wild elephants and other wildlife of the RYER through the use of SMART-managed patrolling and development of staff capacity to allow government and local staff to carry out their duties. This award is provisionally approved for three phases or years funding, with each phase or year's funding dependent upon performance and financial management of the previous phase or year, meeting technical and financial reporting requirements, and availability of ASECF funds. You and your organization are not representatives of the United States Government or the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. You should not hold yourself or your organization out to be representatives of the United States Government or the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. You are not to engage in any kind of intelligence gathering activities or do work or activities in a law enforcement capacity. Prohibited intelligence gathering or law enforcement activities include, but are not limited to, buying or purchasing of intelligence, evidence, or information; engaging a person to be an informant and/or paying an informant; gathering information by persons who conceal their true identity; purchasing firearms or ammunition; or any activity that would circumvent sanctions, laws, or regulations of either the U.S. or the country in which the activity would occur. However, if you come across any information in the course of your grant work on specific crimes enforceable by the United States Government or other related information on criminal activities, you are obligated to turn this information over to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service or the Department of Justice.. participating-org.usg:office-name: Fish and Wildlife Service/Office of International Affairs

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: Foreign assistance aims to deepen Burma's democratic reforms, advance the national reconciliation process, and improve the lives of millions left vulnerable by decades of military rule. By bolstering support for civil society, U.S. efforts aim to strengthen political reforms, advance the national peace process, expand economic opportunity, and improve the health and welfare of all the people of Burma. The signing of a Nationwide Ceasefire Agreement in 2015 has raised expectations for national reconciliation and political dialogue in order to end the conflict. While the landslide victory for Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) party was a historic milestone for the country's trajectory toward greater freedom and opportunity, progress may be undermined by conflict, intercommunal violence, limits on constitutional reform, and weak economic foundations. U.S. assistance aims to support Burma's continued transition and respond to new opportunities critical for Burma to become a more democratic, peaceful, stable, and prosperous country.
